au.edu.jcu.v4l4j
Class YUVFrameGrabber

java.lang.Object
  au.edu.jcu.v4l4j.YUVFrameGrabber
All Implemented Interfaces:
FrameGrabber
public class YUVFrameGrabber
extends java.lang.Object

Objects of this class are used to retrieve YUV420-encoded frames from a VideoDevice. A YUV420 frame grabber can only be created if the associated video device can produce images in a format v4l4j knows how to encode in YUV420. The VideoDevice.supportYUVConversion() method can be used to find out whether a video device can have its images YUV420-encoded by v4l4j, ie if a YUV420 frame grabber can be instantiated. YUVFrameGrabber objects are not instantiated directly. Instead, the VideoDevice.getYUVFrameGrabber(int, int, int, int) or VideoDevice.getYUVFrameGrabber(int, int, int, int, ImageFormat) method must be called on the associated VideoDevice. YUV frame grabbers implement the FrameGrabber interface which provides methods to handle video capture. See its documentation for more information.

Author:
gilles
See Also:
{@link FrameGrabber}

Method Detail

getImageFormat

public ImageFormat getImageFormat()
This method returns the native image format used by this FrameGrabber. The returned format specifies the image format the capture uses, ie the one images are retrieved from the device BEFORE YUV conversion.

Returns:
the native image format used by this FrameGrabber.
Throws:
StateException - if this FrameGrabber has been already released, and therefore must not be used anymore.

getNumberOfRecycledVideoFrames

public int getNumberOfRecycledVideoFrames()
Description copied from interface: FrameGrabber
This method returns the number of recycled video frames, ie. the number of video frames are currently available to v4l4j (and the driver) to store new incoming frames. This number indicates how many more frames can be captured by v4l4j before the capture stops until one of the previous frame gets recycled.

Specified by:
getNumberOfRecycledVideoFrames in interface FrameGrabber
Returns:
the number of video frames currently recycled.

getNumberOfVideoFrames

public int getNumberOfVideoFrames()
Description copied from interface: FrameGrabber
This method returns the number of buffers v4l4j has negotiated with the driver. The driver stores captured frames in these buffers and returns them to v4l4j. A VideoFrame represents (and encapsulates) one of these buffers. Hence, this number is an indication as to how many video frames can be obtained from the driver through FrameGrabber.getVideoFrame() before the capture stops until a buffer is returned to the driver through VideoFrame.recycle(). Practically speaking, this number specifies how many times you can call FrameGrabber.getVideoFrame() before the method blocks, waiting for one of the previous frame to be recycled.

Specified by:
getNumberOfVideoFrames in interface FrameGrabber
Returns:
the number of frame buffers used to retrieve frames from the driver

getVideoFrame

public final VideoFrame getVideoFrame()
                               throws V4L4JException
Description copied from interface: FrameGrabber
This is a legacy method, it will be removed. Do not use it.
This method blocks and waits for a frame, then returns it. If you call this method, make sure either FrameGrabber.startCapture() has already been called, or another thread will call it in the near future, as FrameGrabber.getVideoFrame() will block if capture is not started.

Specified by:
getVideoFrame in interface FrameGrabber
Returns:
an VideoFrame containing the captured frame data.
Throws:
V4L4JException - if there is an error capturing from the source.

setCaptureCallback

public final void setCaptureCallback(CaptureCallback callback)
Description copied from interface: FrameGrabber
setCaptureCallback sets the CaptureCallback object which will be notified by this grabber as soon as new frames become available.
This method cannot be called while the capture is active, ie. in between a call to FrameGrabber.startCapture() and FrameGrabber.stopCapture().

Specified by:
setCaptureCallback in interface FrameGrabber
Parameters:
callback - an object implementing the CaptureCallback interface which will receive new frames and capture exceptions.

setFrameInterval

public void setFrameInterval(int num,
                             int denom)
                      throws InvalidValue
Description copied from interface: FrameGrabber
This method sets the frame interval used for capture. The frame interval defined the lapse of time (in second) between two captured frames and is the inverse of the frame rate. It may or may not be supported by the underlying hardware/driver. If not supported, calling this method throws a UnsupportedMethod exception. This method will throw an InvalidValue exception if the given frame interval value is not supported. As a guide, you can check the ResolutionInfo objects associated with the video device to find out whether frame intervals are at all supported, and if they are, what values (or range of values) are accepted. ResolutionInfo objects can be obtained for each ImageFormat. See the ImageFormat and ResolutionInfo documentation for more information.

Specified by:
setFrameInterval in interface FrameGrabber
Parameters:
num - the numerator of the frame interval to be set
denom - the denominator of the frame interval to be set
Throws:
InvalidValue - if the given frame interval value is invalid.
